Douglas do Couto Teixeira

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/5404425265470615
  • Última atualização do currículo em 28/07/2019

Doutorando em Ciência da Computação na Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG), com período sanduíche no Inria Saclay Île-De-France. Também na UFMG, concluiu o mestrado e a graduação em Ciência da Computação. Ainda durante a graduação, foi estudante de intercâmbio na Universidade do Texas em Austin, nos Estados Unidos. Tem experiência na área de Ciência da Computação, com ênfase em Compiladores e Otimização de Código, Computação Urbana, e predição de mobilidade. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - 2015
Compiler Support for MMT Architectures
Descrição: The low cost, high-performance, and increasing popularity of Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) have brought to the everyday programmer the computational power available only in super-computing centers. However, in order to benefit from all this power, developers still must master a hardware that is still very difficult to program. These difficulties stem from two phenomena that were not present in ordinary computational systems. The first of these idiosyncrasies is the fact that CPUs and GPUs do not share memory: data must be copied from host to device, and back. Such transfers are expensive, and may shadow the performance benefit expected from the parallel hardware. The second phenomena is due to divergences: Branches cause threads to remain idle, while others do work. Consequently, only very regular applications can unleash the GPU's full power. The goal of this dissertation is to present solutions to mitigate both these problems. To free developers from the tedious task of determining in which part of the hardware each computation should run, we provide a suite of static analyses. These analyses find program parts that are super linear - thus paying the cost of the data transfer in for large inputs, and that is not very divergent. This is exactly the code routines that most benefit from the GPU. To reduce divergences, we introduce a novel optimization - the fusion of calling sites - which joins function call sites to avoid that different threads call functions divergently.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Douglas do Couto Teixeira - Integrante / Fernando Magno Quintão Pereira - Coordenador / Sylvain Collange - Integrante.
